TopicTitle: The Most Certainly Unoffical KSP Trivia Thread

Articles.Content:
This is where you dump all the trivia about KSP you can think of. There was something like this, but it's over a month old at this point. I'll start.

Despite Squad classifying them as dwarf planets, Dres and Eeloo currently meet the International Astronomical Union's definition of a proper planet.

It is possible to climb both flag flag poles at the space center.

If you crash into the unclickable building at the KSC, it will say that the building is Mission Control.
Pressing Space will reset the part rotation. (In VAB and SPH, I suspect.)

For real??? I must do this!!!

Pressing Space will reset the part rotation. (In VAB and SPH, I suspect.)

It also resets the view rotation when you're not holding a part (only found that one out today)
Struts kill the decouplers' ejection force.

Struts kill the decouplers' ejection force.

This only happens with stack separators. Normal decouplers work fine, but stack separators won't move at all if the two stages are strutted together.

This thread is now decouplers! (thanks Giggleplex!)
You can jump over 1,000 meters up on Gilly.
Holding down the middle mouse button in-flight will pivot the camera off center of the craft(like in this photo); double-click MMB to reset view.
The Kerbal language (in trailers) is Spanish, played backwards and sped up.
Explosions actually generate a shockwave, which can be used to launch Kerbals great distances.

I juts laughed so hard.... Thank you for that.

You can place a docking port or radial attachment node on top of a parachute, allowing you to build things like escape towers with a stack parachute.

In EVA, space makes a Kerbal let go of a ladder, but Shift+space will have them push themselves away from a ladder!

Normally, a Kerbal in EVA will face the direction they are walking in, but if you press Alt, they will always face away from the camera!

Edited July 27, 2013 by rryy

In EVA, space makes a Kerbal let go of a ladder, but Shift+space will have them push themselves away from a ladder!

And shift + w/a/s/d + space will have them push themselves in the specified direction. This allows to easily transfer between parallel ladders for example.

KSP doesn't actually provide any units for fuel volumes, so no direct comparison can be made. It can be assumed that each unit of fuel is actually 5 litres (which actually fills the volume of the tank quite nicely) and makes liquid fuel and oxidiser roughly comparable to RP-1 and LOx in terms of their properties, which makes more sense.

Kerbin's atmosphere was all the same pressure when it extended to 35km. It was essentially a thick shell of air that made it more efficient to go straight up until you left the atmosphere, and then burn parallel to the ground to get into orbit.

Nice shuttle by the way, it's quite an achievement to get one working nicely!
